.NEXT YEAR....WOMEN.
By RICHARD B. CRAMER

The Academic Council has recommended to
President Gordon that Hopkins admit women
undergraduates for the Fall term of next year.
The Council's recommendations, passed in
its Wednesday meeting, call for GOrdon to
appoint a "task force committee" to report
to the Academic Council with full details on
the institution of general undergraduate coeducation.
Until this task force completes its work ,it
will not be known how many women will be
admitted and in which classes, or if the total
size of the undergraduate body will be changed.
"Some Women"
The Council, however, did specify that
it wanted "some women" to be admitted for
enrollment next year. The statement released
by Dean Kimball's office yesterday said that
it was the Council's intent that Hopkins "proceed as rapidly as feasible to a significant proportion of females in the undergraduate body."
Council members were generally unwilling to
talk about the decision yesterday. The members
of the task force have not been named by
the President. The recommendations of the
Academic Council must be approved by Gordon
and the Board of Trustees before they may be
acted upon. Although Gordon was unavailable
for comment yesterday, it is assumed that he
will react favorably to the recommendations.
The next meeting of the Board of Trustees will
take place on November 10.
The task force will consist of two members
of the faculty, two undergraduates, one rep-

resentative from Dean Kimball's office, and one
representative from the Office of Robert F.
Kerley, the Vice-President for Administration.
"Soon,"Very Soon

Director of Admissions William Brinldey said that
that he would meet the committee's recommendations "soon" in' order to do an effective job of recruiting for the Fall term. "I'm
not ready to move until I get the answers,"
he said. Another administrative source said
that the report of the task force would probably
have to be submitted by November 15 for
coeducation to be successfully implemented
next year.
Brinkley was enthusiastic about the possibilities which coeducation would provide for
Hopkins. He said he wanted to see it become
part of "our total program." He also stated
that it might benefit the recruiting efforts of
the ,University by making Hopkins more attractive to men. Ronald 0 wens, Assistant Director
of Admissions, said that the coeducation move
would indicate a general improvement in the
social conditions at Hopkins.
Already Interviewing
Brinkley stated that the University was already receiving letters from women. His staff
has already been talking to female high school
seniors. However, he stated, that he also wished
to enroll transfer students. "I think we could
get some fine young ladies through transfer,"
he said. No one was willing to speculate on
how many women would be enrolled in each
class. Presumably, the women will enroll in

the Freshmen class more than any other.
According to Homewood House sources,President Gordon views the task force as responsible
for reporting on every aspect of the changes
required for coeducation. This indicates that
the committee will look into everything from
•alterations in the curriculum to placing
"men" and "women" signs on the doors of
lavatories.
Administrators have been looking into the
problems and possibilities of undergraduate coeducation for some time. Recently, the
Academic Council affirmed undergraduate coeducation "in principle."

No Merger
There had been discussion of the feasibility
of merging with Goucher College instead of
admitting women to Hopkins. It was felt by
some that because Goucher already had all of
the facilities which women require, Hopkins
would be wiser to attempt the merger.
The faculty at Hopkins, however, was largely
against the move. There was a fear that faculty
members here would lose the control which
they exercise over curriculum and program requirements if the university merged with
Goucher. Many faculty members were upset
over the types of courses offered in the
Goucher-Hopkins cooperative•program.
In addition, problems of transportation between the two campuses would have proved
difficult to eliminate. Had Hopkins and Goucher
merged, the university would have accrued no
financial advantages. Goucher's endowment is
small compared to that of Hopkins.

they never gave us. As a result, we play nursery school
games with administrators and at the same time we are
captives of a social ethos which worships youth.

Folk Hero No. 1
The hippy, including the many that imitate him, is
purportedly the vanguard of the future, but actually is
merely the anachronistic hero of old, slightly modified.
As a result, he wears the costume of the WWI doughdoy, the headband of the American Indian, the sideburns of the western Plainsman or the smock of the
French Bohemian painter. He couples an antique figurine appearance with the noral . position that life in
any society that demands intelligence is a waste of
precious time. "There is as much surface presence
and internal absence," writes Aldridge, "as one would
expect to find in the most promising junior executive
at General Motors."
In an era of interest in communication among the
young, and the era of most need for substantive personal
interaction, the hippy offers us a life that is "all a
matter of soul speaking to soul, lovers passionately
sweating skin to skin, blown minds exchanging psychedelic
mash-notes--non thoughts floating in non words between
non-entities." Empty minds, fearful of intellectural
stimuli, always capitulate.

Folk Hero No. 2
The activist type is a man of action and little else.
The important thing to the activist is not the problem
to which he addresses himself but the riotous fervor

Never Suffered

employed to effect its solution. Individual action against
real social ills is sacrificed to the mass hysteria
demanding that someone, somewhere, somehow, perfect the world before we are forced to enter it. The
instant gratification of the nursery carried all the way
to the university (because our parents let us do their
living for them), finally meets some authority against
which we rebel, often for no real reason. Since everyone tells us how very smart we are, no one has to do any
mind-work, only mouth-work.
It is the ultimate paradox, however, that we offer
a materialistic solution to very problem in a society
which we accuse of gross materialism. Worst of all,
we criticize the inhuman quality of encroaching technology
in the "New -Speak" of technology. We do not solve
problems in rhetoric, but of course that is the master
strategy. For if the problems were solved we would
be out of work.
It is not that we haven't recognized legitimate social
ills, it is simply that we create an emotional social
environment which makes their solution more remote.

We've Never Suffered
Youth today, above all else, suffers the ignominy
of never having suffered. We had no depression to spawn
material want; no war to instill in us an emotional
attachment to country.
The demand everywhere is for relevance. However,
it would require some thought to realize that after our
technology begins to master our environment(relevance),
we will exist in an atmosphere of cultural atrophy because
of our insistance that all learning must relate to the
present.
If we adulate the hippy who lives a sensuous existence or the activist who acts in a mental vacuum,
where will the intellect reside? One could fear the polarization of all youth into two extreme types; Vegetable
Man and Violent Mechanical Man, the future's models
or the present folk heroes. Much depends on the extent
to which we believe our own vacuous rhetoric; if we
follow types or if we reassert individual identity and
action. If our concern is employment of blacks, we

had better strive for those positions in society which
can offer employment.

Yawning at the Mirror

to the challenge. We are very bored, undoubtedly more
so than housewives mesmerized by daytime television.
If the problem is a lack of identity, it is perplexing to
see how this is overcome simply the assertion of primitive masculinity in the form of mass protest. At the
personal level we are, of course, convinced of our total
individuality, unaware that personal expression, today, is
obviously a mirror image of mass expression.
We are mostly appearance, clawing at the past in
the guise of future quest. It is confusing how we think
ourselves more individual by exchanging one costume
for another or by our desire to shock instead of to
placate. The General Motors type, for all his emptiness,
knows where he is going and does his job well. We do
nothing well, nor want to. Our choice is between careers
that are more often than not "two identical glasses of
sour milk." The ethos of instant gratification puts the
perception of acheivement beyond the
present into
categories, all of which are horribly establishmentarian.
If we commit ourselves we are a part of some system,
some closted circuit. We are not dedicated to anything
and would rather do something boring to collect some
pay than settle into one of those terrible niches. It
would negate the safety of mass orthodoxy.
We are very religious. We speak of others and the
quality of otherness, never, of course, being alone long
enough to comprehend such a thing. Our sexual mores
center on ejaculation and cannot be confined to that neat
little box called the family, whether or not it is the basic
animal and human structure of socity.
It is dangerous to criticize youth. When some of
those adults which are not captivated by us do so, they
are encroaching on some psychological Godhead, the
very personality of society.

through large government defense contracts, our present

expense.

tof _administrative personnel and expertise. This is not

vestiges of control you have over your own life.

the problems of an economy based on defense expenditures, while he cannot offer any alternative programs that even border on reality.

Today's Youth:
By CHRISTOPHER OLANDER
The university today, writes John Aldridge in "Harper's," has the misfortune of being the repository for
the two folk heroes of modern youth who motivate
either our life styles or our activities. The emulation of
types is not in itself deplorable; what is deplorable is
that the types to be copied do not even live in the present.
The permissive parents of a generation tired of
war and poverty sent us to the universities to act out
the emotional conflict between parent and child which
they never gave us. As a result, we play nursery school
games with administrators and at the same time we are
captives of a social ethos which worships youth.

Folk Hero No. 1
The hippy, including the many that imitate him, is
purportedly the vanguard of the future, but actually is
merely the anachronistic hero of old, slightly modified.
As a result, he wears the costume of the WWI doughdoy, the headband of the American Indian, the sideburns of the western Plainsman or the smock of the
French Bohemian painter. He couples an antique figurine appearance with the noral . position that life in
any society that demands intelligence is a waste of
precious time. "There is as much surface presence
and internal absence," writes Aldridge, "as one would
expect to find in the most promising junior executive
at General Motors."
In an era of interest in communication among the
young, and the era of most need for substantive personal
interaction, the hippy offers us a life that is "all a
matter of soul speaking to soul, lovers passionately
sweating skin to skin, blown minds exchanging psychedelic
mash-notes--non thoughts floating in non words between
non-entities." Empty minds, fearful of intellectural
stimuli, always capitulate.

Folk Hero No. 2
The activist type is a man of action and little else.
The important thing to the activist is not the problem
to which he addresses himself but the riotous fervor

Never Suffered

employed to effect its solution. Individual action against
real social ills is sacrificed to the mass hysteria
demanding that someone, somewhere, somehow, perfect the world before we are forced to enter it. The
instant gratification of the nursery carried all the way
to the university (because our parents let us do their
living for them), finally meets some authority against
which we rebel, often for no real reason. Since everyone tells us how very smart we are, no one has to do any
mind-work, only mouth-work.
It is the ultimate paradox, however, that we offer
a materialistic solution to very problem in a society
which we accuse of gross materialism. Worst of all,
we criticize the inhuman quality of encroaching technology
in the "New -Speak" of technology. We do not solve
problems in rhetoric, but of course that is the master
strategy. For if the problems were solved we would
be out of work.
It is not that we haven't recognized legitimate social
ills, it is simply that we create an emotional social
environment which makes their solution more remote.

We've Never Suffered
Youth today, above all else, suffers the ignominy
of never having suffered. We had no depression to spawn
material want; no war to instill in us an emotional
attachment to country.
The demand everywhere is for relevance. However,
it would require some thought to realize that after our
technology begins to master our environment(relevance),
we will exist in an atmosphere of cultural atrophy because
of our insistance that all learning must relate to the
present.
If we adulate the hippy who lives a sensuous existence or the activist who acts in a mental vacuum,
where will the intellect reside? One could fear the polarization of all youth into two extreme types; Vegetable
Man and Violent Mechanical Man, the future's models
or the present folk heroes. Much depends on the extent
to which we believe our own vacuous rhetoric; if we
follow types or if we reassert individual identity and
action. If our concern is employment of blacks, we

had better strive for those positions in society which
can offer employment.

Yawning at the Mirror
There is much concern as to whether we are up
to the challenge. We are very bored, undoubtedly more
so than housewives mesmerized by daytime television.
If the problem is a lack of identity, it is perplexing to
see how this is overcome simply the assertion of primitive masculinity in the form of mass protest. At the
personal level we are, of course, convinced of our total
individuality, unaware that personal expression, today, is
obviously a mirror image of mass expression.
We are mostly appearance, clawing at the past in
the guise of future quest. It is confusing how we think
ourselves more individual by exchanging one costume
for another or by our desire to shock instead of to
placate. The General Motors type, for all his emptiness,
knows where he is going and does his job well. We do
nothing well, nor want to. Our choice is between careers
that are more often than not "two identical glasses of
sour milk." The ethos of instant gratification puts the
perception of acheivement beyond the
present into
categories, all of which are horribly establishmentarian.
If we commit ourselves we are a part of some system,
some closted circuit. We are not dedicated to anything
and would rather do something boring to collect some
pay than settle into one of those terrible niches. It
would negate the safety of mass orthodoxy.
We are very religious. We speak of others and the
quality of otherness, never, of course, being alone long
enough to comprehend such a thing. Our sexual mores
center on ejaculation and cannot be confined to that neat
little box called the family, whether or not it is the basic
animal and human structure of socity.
It is dangerous to criticize youth. When some of
those adults which are not captivated by us do so, they
are encroaching on some psychological Godhead, the
very personality of society.

The Roman Catholic Synod of Bishops concluded its
1969 sessionthisweek in a spirit of almost universal
satisfaction among the participants.
The tabulation of voting during their meetings showed
only one issue on which delegates failed to demonstrate
near unanimity. This was the question of whether lay and
priest experts should be permitted to assist the bishop
delegates at future synod sessions.
Experts had a powerful impact on the shape of the
decisions made at the Second Vatican Council, but were
excluded from this synod and the one in 1967. Of the 143
bishops voting, 97 balloted in favor of admitting the experts in the future, 25 opposed the idea, 18 favored it with
qualifications and 3 abstained.

issues on which the synod sought to find a common mind,
attracted a large number of qualified yes votes. One of
these was clearly drafted with the intent of guaranteeing
that no future papal encyclical, except in extraordinary
circumstances, will be metwith thewidespread opposition
that greeted "Humanae Vitae," the 1967 letter renewing
the ban on contraception.
The second issue tactfully propsed the "collaboration"
of the bishops' national conference in the Pope's preparation of documents concerning the unity of the faith and the
